paper_id: Standing Biomass, Dry-Matter Production, and Nutrient Demand of Tenera Oil Palm

paper_metadata.title: Standing Biomass, Dry-Matter Production, and Nutrient Demand of Tenera Oil Palm
paper_metadata.primary_focus: Quantifying standing biomass, dry-matter production, and nutrient demand of tenera oil palm of different ages under current agronomic practices.

research_methodology.experimental_design: Destructive sampling of tenera oil palms of different ages (12, 29, 48, 88, 133, 209, and 238 months old) from commercial plantations under current agromanagement practices. Four palms were randomly sampled from each age group, excluding stunted, abnormal, and roadside palms.

temporal_scope.data_collection_frequency: Single destructive sampling event for each age group
temporal_scope.seasonal_coverage: Not specified, but annual rainfall data from 2011-2019 provided

site_characteristics: Oil-palm plantation with 129 blocks (5.1 to 34.8 hectares each)
Dominant soil type: Harimau Series (Typic Paleudult)
Undulating topography with slopes ranging from 2 to 6 degrees

sample_design.replication_levels: 4 replicates per age group for destructive sampling
sample_design.randomization_approach: Four palms from each age group were randomly sampled.
controls_and_treatments: No explicit control group; comparison is across different palm ages and with historical data/other studies.
Treatment is 'current Sime Darby Plantation agromanagement practices' including annual fertilization.
sample_design.statistical_power: Not explicitly stated, but p-values and SE are provided.

measurement_protocols: Destructive sampling: Palms harvested, uprooted, and separated into morphological components (leaves, leaf bases, spear leaves, cabbage, trunk, bole, roots, inflorescences, bunches).
Dry weight determination: Palm organs wiped clean, cut into smaller pieces, dried to constant weight (50-70°C) using Memmert laboratory oven Model UF450.
Total N: Combustion method with elemental analyzer (temperature 900°C).
P: Colorimetrically by yellow phosphovanadate complex using AutoAnalyzer after dry-ashing.
K, Mg, Ca: Atomic Absorption Spectrophotometer after dry-ashing.
B: Azomethine method using UV Spectrophotometer after dry-ashing with H2SO4.
instrumentation: Memmert laboratory oven Model UF450 (Memmert GmbH, Schwabach, Germany)
Atomic Absorption Spectrophotometer (for K, Mg, Ca)
quality_control: Palm organs wiped clean with distilled water before analysis.

analysis_methods: Nonlinear regression analysis (TableCurve 2D version 5.1) for cumulative dry matter (spear leaves, trunk, bole).
JMP® Version 14 (SAS Institute Inc.) for dry weight, dry-matter production, and nutrient concentrations data.
Pearson correlations for tissue nutrient concentrations with palm age.
statistical_approach.significance_testing: Means separated by Tukey HSD test procedure at the threshold significant level of 5% (p ≤ 0.05).
statistical_approach.model_validation: Parsimonious models with low fitting standard error and high R^2 selected for dry matter estimation (R^2 > 0.90 for most equations).

primary_measurements.parameter: Total standing vegetative biomass (excluding roots)
Total standing vegetative biomass (excluding roots)
Whole-palm dry-matter production
Whole-palm dry-matter production
primary_measurements.measurement_context: After 133 months, with little increase thereafter

primary_measurements.parameter: Annual gross N demand for 25 t FFB ha⁻¹
Annual gross P demand for 25 t FFB ha⁻¹
Annual gross K demand for 25 t FFB ha⁻¹
Annual gross Mg demand for 25 t FFB ha⁻¹
Annual gross Ca demand for 25 t FFB ha⁻¹
Annual gross B demand for 25 t FFB ha⁻¹
Annual net N demand for 25 t FFB ha⁻¹ (pruned leaves recycled)
Annual net P demand for 25 t FFB ha⁻¹ (pruned leaves recycled)
Annual net K demand for 25 t FFB ha⁻¹ (pruned leaves recycled)
Annual net Mg demand for 25 t FFB ha⁻¹ (pruned leaves recycled)
Annual net Ca demand for 25 t FFB ha⁻¹ (pruned leaves recycled)
Annual net B demand for 25 t FFB ha⁻¹ (pruned leaves recycled)
Nutrient content in tenera fresh fruit bunches (FFB)
Nutrient content in tenera fresh fruit bunches (FFB)
Nutrient content in tenera fresh fruit bunches (FFB)
Nutrient content in tenera fresh fruit bunches (FFB)
Nutrient content in tenera fresh fruit bunches (FFB)
Nutrient content in tenera fresh fruit bunches (FFB)

temporal_patterns.trend_description: Increased almost linearly with palm age.
Increased with palm age but at a decreasing rate, stabilizing after 133 months.

temporal_patterns.parameter: Annual N, P, Mg, Ca, and B demand
temporal_patterns.trend_description: Followed annual vegetative dry-matter production, with low demand during the first 12 months, rapid increase up to 88 months, slower increase up to 209 months (peak), then decline at 238 months.
Declined sharply after peaking at month 88, and only reverted upward at month 238.

comparative_results.practical_significance: N and Mg lower, P comparable, K and Ca higher in this study.
N and Mg comparable, P, K, and Ca higher in this study.

groups_compared: Goh et al. [4,5], Teoh and Chew [18] (Tenera)
comparative_results.practical_significance: N, P, K, and Ca higher than previously studied dura and tenera, except for Mg in mature dura.

comparative_results.comparison_type: Nutrient content in fresh fruit bunches
comparative_results.practical_significance: Tenera bunches in this study are much richer in N, P, K, Mg, and Ca than previously studied dura and tenera bunches.

comparative_results.comparison_type: Annual gross nutrient demand (25 t FFB ha⁻¹)
comparative_results.practical_significance: 53% more N, 57% more P, 132% more K, 64% more Ca, and 2% higher Mg demand in this study's tenera compared to dura.

comparative_results.comparison_type: Annual net B demand (25 t FFB ha⁻¹)
comparative_results.practical_significance: No difference found, both required 2.5 g palm⁻¹.

comparative_results.comparison_type: Annual net nutrient demand (25 t FFB ha⁻¹, pruned leaves recycled)
comparative_results.practical_significance: Higher net nutrient demand in this study's tenera compared to previously studied fully fertilized mature dura and tenera.

geographic_details.landscape_position: Undulating, with slopes ranging from 2 to 6°

soil_properties.texture: 30% clay, 3% silt, 34% fine sand, 29% coarse sand
soil_properties.organic_matter: Not explicitly stated as OM, but 0.13% total N is given

land_use_context.management_intensity: Commercial, current Sime Darby Plantation agromanagement practices (fertilized annually)
land_use_context.historical_context: Not specified, but implies continuous oil palm cultivation

yield_levels.fresh_fruit_bunches_ha_yr: 25 t ha⁻¹ year⁻¹ (for nutrient demand calculation)
yield_levels.fresh_fruit_bunches_palm_yr: 36.0 kg palm⁻¹ year⁻¹ (at 48 months), 77.9 kg palm⁻¹ year⁻¹ (at 88 months), 100.6 kg palm⁻¹ year⁻¹ (at 133 months), 121.1 kg palm⁻¹ year⁻¹ (at 209 months), 95.8 kg palm⁻¹ year⁻¹ (at 238 months)

rates.12_months_old: 0.04 kg N, 0.02 kg P, 0.02 kg K, 0.01 kg Mg, 0 kg Ca, 0 kg B per palm year⁻¹
rates.29_months_old: 0.60 kg N, 0.51 kg P, 0.71 kg K, 0.06 kg Mg, 0.57 kg Ca, 0 kg B per palm year⁻¹
rates.48_months_old: 0.66 kg N, 0.40 kg P, 1.06 kg K, 0.12 kg Mg, 0.52 kg Ca, 0.009 kg B per palm year⁻¹
rates.88_months_old: 0.97 kg N, 0.21 kg P, 1.93 kg K, 0.28 kg Mg, 0.52 kg Ca, 0.009 kg B per palm year⁻¹
rates.133_months_old: 0.89 kg N, 0.24 kg P, 1.91 kg K, 0.26 kg Mg, 0.72 kg Ca, 0.009 kg B per palm year⁻¹
rates.209_months_old: 0.89 kg N, 0.22 kg P, 1.99 kg K, 0.26 kg Mg, 0.70 kg Ca, 0.009 kg B per palm year⁻¹
rates.238_months_old: 0.85 kg N, 0.21 kg P, 1.85 kg K, 0.23 kg Mg, 0.63 kg Ca, 0.009 kg B per palm year⁻¹

organic_amendments: Recycling of pruned leaves (hypothetical scenario for net nutrient demand)

input_rates.fertilizer_rates: As per Table 1, varying by palm age.

output_measurements.nutrient_demand: 18 g N to 2.34 kg N per palm (total annual demand)

efficiency_metrics.nutrient_partitioning_to_FFB: 37-54% for N, P, Mg, Ca, B; 19-36% for K

balance_calculations.nutrient_balance_sheet: Small deficit of about 46 kg N, 54 kg K, and 11 kg Mg per hectare per year (could be supplied by soil).

study_timeline.start_date: Not explicitly stated for the study, but palm ages start from 12 months since nursery planting.
study_timeline.end_date: Not explicitly stated for the study, but palm ages go up to 238 months since nursery planting.
data_collection_schedule: Palms sampled at 12, 29, 48, 88, 133, 209, and 238 months old.
study_timeline.monitoring_frequency: Single sampling event for each age group.

long_term_trends.trend_units: kg palm⁻¹ at 12 months to 808.6 kg palm⁻¹ at 238 months
kg palm⁻¹ year⁻¹ at 12 months to 285.5 kg palm⁻¹ year⁻¹ after 133 months

long_term_trends.parameter: N and P concentrations in vegetative tissues
long_term_trends.sustainability_implications: Implies dilution effect of biomass accumulation.

long_term_trends.parameter: Mg concentration in leaves and trunk
long_term_trends.sustainability_implications: Implies dilution effect of biomass accumulation.

long_term_trends.parameter: Ca and B concentrations in trunk
long_term_trends.sustainability_implications: Implies dilution effect of biomass accumulation.

drivers_of_variability: Genetic differences among tenera palms (from different genetic origins)

methodological_strengths: Comprehensive destructive sampling of various palm components.
Study covers a wide range of palm ages (12 to 238 months).
Detailed laboratory analysis for multiple nutrients.
Statistical analysis using nonlinear regression and Tukey HSD.
Addresses a significant knowledge gap in updated nutrient demand for tenera oil palm.
methodological_limitations: Root biomass measurement was not made directly; estimated using a ratio from another study (0.104), which is noted as a 'considerably small fraction' and requires 'further studies'.
Fruit bunch weight was obtained from actual bunch weight recorded in a single block, not from all sampled palms.
No explicit control group (e.g., unfertilized palms) for direct comparison of nutrient uptake under different regimes.
Palm-to-palm variations in nutrient concentrations attributed to genetic differences, which could introduce variability.
data_quality_assessment.data_completeness: High, most required parameters are provided with numerical values and units.

measurement_precision.coefficient_of_variation_reported: Yes, for nutrient concentrations in vegetative tissues.

representativeness.spatial_representativeness: Palms selected from blocks with similar terrains and dominant soil type (Harimau Series) to ensure consistency within the study site. Represents Malaysian inland environment.
representativeness.temporal_representativeness: Covers a wide range of palm ages, from nursery to mature, providing a comprehensive temporal profile.
representativeness.system_representativeness: Represents commercial tenera oil palm grown under current agronomic practices in Malaysia.

uncertainty_sources: Estimation of root dry-matter production using a fixed ratio.
Variations in nutrient concentrations due to genetic differences among palms.
Fruit bunch data from a single block may not fully represent all sampled palms.
validation_evidence: Comparison of aboveground dry weight with previous studies on dura and tenera palms in Malaysia and Indonesia showed comparability.
Comparison of dry-matter production with previous studies in Malaysia and West Africa.
Comparison of nutrient concentrations and demand with historical data from dura and tenera studies.

key_methodological_references: Corley et al. [16] for annual leaf dry-matter production calculation.
Henson and Chai [31] for root-to-shoot ratio used in root dry-matter production estimation.
Corley et al. [32] for converting fresh fruit bunches to dry weight.
SIRIM [27] for K, Mg, Ca determination method.
John et al. [28] for B determination method.
comparative_studies: Ng et al. [2] (oil palm nutrition, dura and tenera)
Teoh and Chew [18] (K requirements of tenera)
Goh et al. [4,5] (N, P, K requirements of tenera)
Tarmizi Mohamad and Tayeb Dolmat [6] (nutrient demands of tenera)
Rees and Tinker [15] (dry-matter production and nutrient content of oil palms in Nigeria)
Corley et al. [16] (productivity of oil palm in Malaysia)
Dufrene [38] (photosynthesis, water consumption, and production modeling in oil palm)
Prabowo et al. [19] (recycling oil palm bunch nutrients)
Donough et al. [20] (improving nutrient management on sandy soils)
Goh et al. [21] (boron nutrition of tenera)
literature_integration.theoretical_framework: Growth demand vs. deficiency demand for nutrients; nutrient partitioning and accumulation in different plant tissues.
data_sources: Equation (3) for leaf production rate derived from three oil-palm planting-density trials in Malaysia [30].
benchmarking_data: Previous studies on dry-matter production and nutrient content of dura and tenera oil palms in Malaysia, Indonesia, and West Africa.

extraction_metadata.data_richness_assessment: The paper is rich in quantitative data, including dry weights, nutrient concentrations, and calculated demands, with associated standard errors. Detailed methodological descriptions are also provided.
potential_ambiguities: The exact start and end dates of the study itself are not explicitly stated, only the ages of the sampled palms.
The estimation of root dry-matter production using a fixed ratio is noted as a limitation by the authors.
Fruit bunch weight data was from a single block, which might not fully represent all sampled palms.
extraction_limitations: Specific detection limits for analytical methods were not provided in the text.
Detailed quality control procedures beyond 'wiped clean with distilled water' were not elaborated.
quality_flags: Root biomass and dry-matter production for roots are estimated values.
Fruit bunch data is from a single block.
recommended_validation_checks: Cross-reference the fertilizer application rates in Table 1 with the discussion on nutrient balance (Table S4, if available).
Verify the equations used for dry matter estimation (Equations 1-5) against the cited references if possible.

_usage_metadata.paper_id: Standing Biomass, Dry-Matter Production, and Nutrient Demand of Tenera Oil Palm
